Definition: A name of a computer package, application, method or function used for the analysis of data.
Guidance: Not typically included in an AMR prediction output. The user may have to provide the value.

Definition: The version of software used to analyze data.
Guidance: The version of the software revealed by the version flag such as 'rgi main --version' or 'abricare --version'. Not typically included in an AMR prediction output. Semantic versioning is strongly recommended. If unavailable, provide the date in ISO 8601 format the tool was last updated or installed.

Definition: The name of a gene, (typically) assigned by a person and/or according to a naming scheme. It may contain white space characters and is typically more intuitive and readable than a gene symbol. It (typically) may be used to identify similar genes in different species and to derive a gene symbol.
Guidance: The long name for the gene/protein. Gene names or gene product names are acceptable.

Definition: The short name of a gene; a single word that does not contain white space characters. It is typically derived from the gene name.
Guidance: Acceptable values may represent gene symbols or gene product symbols. "Gene symbol" and "allele" (based on amino acid variations) may be used interchangeably due to nuances in resistance gene family nomenclature. Parsers should include values from the "gene symbol" and "allele" fields in this category.

Definition: The class of genetic variation detected.
Guidance: Select a value from the pick list.
Values: ['Gene presence detected', 'Mutation variation detected', 'Both gene presence and mutation variation detected']

Definition: The name of the file containing the sequence data to be analysed.
Guidance: Name of the file with the input sequence data to be analysed. Tools can have multiple input files (genomic/amino acid). Multiple input files will be accommodated by their corresponding parser.

Definition: An identifier that specifies an individual sequence record in a public sequence repository.
Guidance: No specific guidance.

Definition: An identifier of a biological or bioinformatics database.
Guidance: The name of the reference database may need to be entered manually if not automatically recorded as a paramter within the tool.

Definition: The version of the database containing the reference sequences used for analysis.
Guidance: The version of the reference database may need to be entered manually if not automatically recorded as a parameter within the tool. If unavailable, provide the date in ISO 8601 format the database was last updated or installed.

Definition: A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans.
Guidance: This should describe a specific agent. Standardized terms from the ChEBI ontology should be used. Find terms using https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/chebi. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: The percentage of the reference sequence covered by the sequence of interest.
Guidance: The sequences can refer to reads and genome, nucleotides and genes, or amino acids and proteins. This value should be normalized and expressed as a percentage. Do not include the "%" sign in the value. Either "% Coverage (breadth)" of "Coverage (breadth) is required.

Definition: The average number of reads representing a given nucleotide in the reconstructed sequence.
Guidance: The value is expressed as a fold value e.g. 56x.

Definition: The ratio of the reference sequence covered by the sequence of interest.
Guidance: The sequences can refer to reads and genome, nucleotides and genes, or amino acids and proteins. This value should not be normalized and expressed as the ratio of actual positions being compared e.g. 450/500. Either "% Coverage (breadth)" of "Coverage (breadth) is required.

Definition: In an antimicrobial context, a drug class is a set of antibiotic molecules, including antibiotic/adjuvant combination medications, with similar chemical structures, molecular targets, and/or modes and mechanisms of action.
Guidance: Standardized terms from the ChEBI ontology should be used. Find terms using https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/chebi. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: The length (number of positions) of a target gene sequence submitted by a user.
Guidance: Report the number of nucelotides in the sequence without any units.

Definition: The position of the first nucleotide in a gene sequence being analyzed (input gene sequence).
Guidance: The value should be biologically relevant, and should not start with 0. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: The position of the last nucleotide in a gene sequence being analyzed (input gene sequence).
Guidance: The value should be biologically relevant, and should not start with 0. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: The length (number of positions) of a protein target sequence submitted by a user.
Guidance: Report the number of amino acids in the sequence without any units.

Definition: The position of the first amino acid in a protein sequence being analyzed (input protein sequence).
Guidance: PHA4GE recommends that this value be biologically relevant, and start with 1, however starting at 0 is permissible. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: The position of the last amino acid in a protein sequence being analyzed (input protein sequence).
Guidance: The value should be biologically relevant, and should not start with 0. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: An identifier of molecular sequence(s) or entries from a molecular sequence database.
Guidance: Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: The nucleotide sequence change(s) detected in the sequence being analyzed compared to a reference, represented by a specified notation system.
Guidance: Use HGVS syntax; c. (coding) g.(genomic), or r. (ribosomal) mutations should be included here

Definition: A description of identified nucleotide mutation(s) that facilitate clinical interpretation.
Example: C --> A at the position aligning to 33038255 in the reference genome
Guidance: generated computationally from HGVS string

Definition: A characteristic of an organism that is predicted rather than directly measured or observed.
Example: Expected to contribute to antimicrobial resistance
Guidance: For all AMR tools expects "contributes to resistance"

Definition: The level of confidence in a predicted phenotype.
Guidance: Confidence that we have that the mutation contributes to the phenotype

Definition: The amino acid sequence change(s) detected in the sequence being analyzed compared to a reference, represented by a specified notation system.
Guidance: Use HGVS syntax; p. (protein) mutations should be included here; use 3 letter code preferred for amino acids

Definition: A description of identified amino acid mutation(s) that facilitate clinical interpretation.
Example: amino acid Trp24 is changed to a Cys
Guidance: generated computationally from HGVS string

Definition: The length (number of positions) of a gene reference sequence retrieved from a database.
Guidance: Report the number of nucelotides in the sequence without any units.

Definition: The position of the first nucleotide in a reference gene sequence (sequence being used for comparison).
Guidance: The value should be biologically relevant, and should not start with 0. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: The position of the last nucleotide in a reference sequence (sequence being used for comparison).
Guidance: The value should be biologically relevant, and should not start with 0. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: The length (number of positions) of a protein reference sequence retrieved from a database.
Guidance: Report the number of amino acids in the sequence without any units.

Definition: The position of the first amino acid in a reference protein sequence (sequence being used for comparison).
Guidance: The value should be biologically relevant, and should not start with 0. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: The position of the last amino acid in a reference protein sequence (sequence being used for comparison).
Guidance: The value should be biologically relevant, and should not start with 0. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: Antibiotic resistance mechanisms evolve naturally via natural selection through random mutation, but it could also be engineered by applying an evolutionary stress on a population.
Guidance: Standardized terms from the ChEBI ontology should be used. Find terms using https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ols/ontologies/aro. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: The orientation of a genomic element on the double-stranded molecule.
Guidance: Values should be sense or antisense, or the corresponding short form "+" or "-". The terms "positive" and "negative" should be avoided. Can be left blank if not provided.

Definition: Sequence identity is the number (%) of matches (identical characters) in positions from an alignment of two molecular sequences.
Guidance: The sequences can refer to reads and genome, nucelotides and genes, or amino acids and proteins. The value should be expressed as a percentage. Do not include the "%" sign in the value.
